Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project establishes CalTeach:Physical Sciences and Engineering (CTPSE). The project team includes faculty from the College of Engineering as well as the Departments of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Physics, and Education; high school teachers and principals from two STEM Academies in the high-needs Santa Barbara Unified School District; and program directors and community leaders from UCSB's Mathematics, Engineering, and Science Achievement program, the Dos Pueblos Engineering Academy Foundation, and the Santa Barbara County PreK-20 STEM Council. The project is preparing 24 highly qualified and diverse physics and chemistry teachers. These teachers are implementing the National Research Council's Framework for K-12 Science Education in high-needs secondary schools, specifically, to teach science and engineering core ideas and practices to underserved students. The project team is tracking the professional trajectories of the Teacher Scholars to evaluate their effectiveness as beginning teachers in high-needs schools and to strengthen CTPSE program components in light of evaluation findings.

The broader impacts of this project include increasing UCSB's production of thoroughly trained, highly motivated physics and chemistry teachers by 140%. Strategies found effective in preparing science teachers to integrate engineering and science, and to actively engage students in solving engineering problems and investigating natural phenomena are being widely disseminated. The CTPSE project is improving the teaching of chemistry and physics to underserved students in California, providing more Latinos/as, low-income students, and English learners with access to an excellent and equitable physical science education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Begun in 2013, UC Santa Barbara?s CalTeach Physical Science and Engineering project (CTPSE) successfully recruited, prepared, and retained two groups of effective prospective teachers: (1) high-achieving undergraduate students pursuing degrees in chemistry, physics, engineering. and computer science, who were provided early field opportunities for them to explore teaching as a career; and (2) teacher candidates with strong subject matter backgrounds pursuing a single-subject credential in physics or chemistry, who were provided with opportunities for field placements in exemplary classrooms with exceptional mentor teachers who engaged their students in the NGSS science and engineering practices. Research shows that being taught by experienced, well-prepared teachers improves student outcomes, especially for those students who are underrepresented in STEM and/or who attend a high-needs school.

Because of faculty liaisons from key STEM disciplines and an existing CalTeach undergraduate program on campus, across six years, CTPSE recruited 62 undergraduate students who completed intensive summer field experiences in innovative classrooms. Sixty-eight percent of these interns pursued follow-up opportunities for continuing their work in classrooms. From the intern perspective, the quality of the CTPSE program was centered on the following aspects: (a) the early opportunities they were given to acquire pedagogical skills by applying their content learning to teach individual, small group, and whole classes of students; (b) the relationships they were able to build with students in order to understand how students learn inquiry-based science; and (c) the opportunities they themselves were afforded to acquire practical engineering skills within a problem-based environment. Most of the interns have since graduated, all with degrees in physics, chemistry, computer science, or engineering. Four interns are still pursuing their degrees at UC Santa Barbara and 1 intern has left the university. Twenty-three of the 57 CTPSE intern graduates (40%) pursued careers in education. More specifically, 6 graduates earned secondary teaching credentials (12%) and are currently teaching in high-needs schools, 12 are pursuing PhDs in STEM and considering teaching science at the college level (21%), and 5 are science educators in more informal science settings.

The program was also successful in increasing the number of teacher candidates applying to the teacher education program at UC Santa Barbara by 50%. Twenty-six secondary teachers candidates in physics and chemistry were recruited and awarded the CTPSE Noyce Scholarship. Three of these scholars had been CTPSE undergraduate interns as well. CTPSE scholars completed two methods courses that helped prepare them to teach in accordance with the three-dimensional learning outlined in the NGSS. One of these methods courses, in particular, prepared them to earn the Industrial & Technology Education credential. All CTPSE scholars also completed their student teaching in exemplary junior high and high school classrooms in a local district which is considered high-needs (due to over 50% of the students in this district living in poverty) and ethnically diverse (index of 37).

On a widely used teacher performance assessment (edTPA), CTPSE scholars consistently scored above a national sample of teachers on all of the rubric indicators in instruction and assessment. In particular, they scored highly on indicators critical to teaching in high-needs schools. For example, candidates scored well on those indicators designed to assess their use of evidence to evaluate and change their science teaching practices to meet the varied learning needs of students and on those designed to assess how the candidate analyzes students' use of language to develop science content understanding. They also scored higher than the national comparison group of secondary science candidates on those indicators aligned with teaching NGSS practices. Secondary qualitative analysis of  edTPA lessons were used to triangulate these findings and consistently showed that the CTPSE scholars introduced engineering design into their lessons and implemented intentional combinations of the NGSS practices and crosscutting concepts in order to further their students? science understanding. In addition, CTPSE scholars supported student learning of science by using appropriate and effective instruction for multilingual learners.

All 26 CTPSE Scholars graduated from the program with an M.Ed. and 25 were awarded secondary credentials. Of the 25 CTPSE beginning teachers, 24 found teaching positions upon graduation and 23 of those positions were in high-needs schools. Seven of the CTPSE teachers remained in the district where they completed their student teaching, while the remaining beginning teachers who teach in high-needs districts are currently in schools with higher percentages of students living in poverty, more multilingual learners, and/or with a more diverse student population. Follow-up data show that CTPSE beginning teachers continue to regularly implement specific NGSS science and engineering practices in their classrooms, despite the switch to online learning brought about by the COVID 19 pandemic. They have also assumed considerable leadership responsibilities in order to improve outcomes for high-needs students: cooperating teacher roles, beginning teacher support program mentors, taking leadership for equity roles, serving as curriculum (NGSS) leads, conducting teacher research, and presenting at conferences.
